initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The reigning champion of the prestigious Golden Brush calligraphy competition has been disqualified and banned from participating for two years after allegations of misconduct surfaced.

Wang Jingwei, 35, was accused of using a hidden earpiece to receive tips from her coach during the final round of the competition, which was held at the ancient Temple of Literature in Beijing.

Although the Chinese Calligraphy Association (CCA) could not find conclusive evidence to support the cheating claims, they were forced to take action against Wang due to her unbecoming behaviour at the post-competition banquet.

According to eyewitnesses, Wang became intoxicated and began performing a provocative dance on top of a table, knocking over several plates of food and causing a scene.

The CCA stated that Wang's actions "brought shame to the revered art of calligraphy and violated the dignity of the competition."

As a result, Wang was stripped of her title and prize money, which included a cash award of 50,000 yuan and a scholarship to study calligraphy in Japan.

The celebrated maestro of the esteemed Silver Baton conducting competition has been stripped of his title and banned from performing for three years after accusations of unprofessional conduct emerged.

Leonardo Marquez, 40, was accused of secretly communicating with his mentor through a hidden smartwatch during the final round of the competition, which was held at the iconic Carnegie Hall in New York.

Although the International Conductors' Guild (ICG) could not find definitive proof to support the allegations, they were compelled to take action against Marquez due to his inappropriate behavior at the post-competition gala.

According to witnesses, Marquez became belligerent and began arguing with a fellow competitor, eventually shattering a glass award on the floor and causing a disturbance.

The ICG stated that Marquez's actions "tarnished the respected art of conducting and undermined the integrity of the competition."

As a result, Marquez was stripped of his title and prize package, which included a cash award of $100,000 and a recording contract with a prestigious label.

The renowned Chef Auguste, winner of the coveted Golden Whisk award, has been disqualified and banned from competing in any culinary events for five years after allegations of dishonesty surfaced.

Remy LaFleur, 35, was accused of smuggling a miniature culinary encyclopedia into the competition kitchen via a hidden compartment in his chef's coat, giving him an unfair advantage in the final round of the prestigious Bocuse d'Or competition.

Although the World Chef Federation (WCF) couldn't find concrete evidence to support the claims, they took disciplinary action against LaFleur due to his unsportsmanlike behavior during the post-competition dinner.

Witnesses reported that LaFleur became aggressive and confrontational, eventually upending a table and causing a scene. The WCF declared that LaFleur's actions "sullied the noble art of cooking and compromised the integrity of the competition."

As a consequence, LaFleur was stripped of his title and prizes, including a cash award of $50,000 and a cookbook deal with a prominent publisher.

The illustrious Maestro Rodriguez, winner of the coveted Golden Baton award, has been expelled and banned from conducting in any major orchestras for three years after allegations of deceit surfaced.

Elena Vasquez, 40, was accused of using a hidden earpiece to receive real-time guidance from a renowned conductor during the prestigious Tchaikovsky Competition, giving her an unfair edge in the final round.

Although the International Conductors' Guild (ICG) couldn't find conclusive proof to support the claims, they took disciplinary action against Vasquez due to her unprofessional behavior during the post-competition reception.

Witnesses reported that Vasquez became defensive and argumentative, eventually storming out of the room and leaving a trail of upset in her wake. The ICG declared that Vasquez's actions "tarnished the noble art of music and undermined the integrity of the competition."

As a consequence, Vasquez was stripped of her title and prizes, including a recording contract with a prominent label and a coveted position as guest conductor with the Berlin Philharmonic.

Renowned Chef Delacroix, celebrated for his three Michelin stars, has been banned from participating in international culinary competitions for five years after allegations of sabotage surfaced.

Marc Dupont, 35, was accused of secretly tampering with his opponents' dishes during the prestigious Bocuse d'Or, giving him an unfair advantage in the final round.

Although the World Chef Federation (WCF) couldn't find conclusive evidence to support the claims, they took disciplinary action against Dupont due to his unprofessional behavior during the post-competition press conference.

Witnesses reported that Dupont became aggressive and dismissive, eventually shouting at a journalist and storming out of the room. The WCF declared that Dupont's actions "tainted the noble art of cuisine and undermined the integrity of the competition."

As a consequence, Dupont was stripped of his title and prizes, including a cookbook deal with a prominent publisher and a coveted position as head chef at a luxurious restaurant in Paris.

Acclaimed Violinist, Maestro Rodriguez, known for his mesmerizing performances, has been suspended from participating in global music competitions for three years following allegations of intellectual property theft.

Ana Moreno, 32, was accused of plagiarizing a renowned composer's concerto, passing it off as her own original work, and performing it at the prestigious Tchaikovsky Competition.

Although the International Music Federation (IMF) couldn't find definitive proof to support the claims, they took disciplinary action against Moreno due to her evasive behavior during the post-competition interview.

Witnesses reported that Moreno became defensive and hostile, eventually refusing to answer questions and storming out of the room. The IMF declared that Moreno's actions "sullied the revered art of music and compromised the integrity of the competition."

As a consequence, Moreno was stripped of her title and prizes, including a recording contract with a prominent label and a coveted spot as concertmaster at a prestigious orchestra in Berlin.

Celebrated novelist, Sophia Patel, has been stripped of her literary awards and barred from publishing for five years after allegations of literary theft surfaced, accusing her of passing off a critically acclaimed author's unpublished manuscript as her own.

Although the Literary Guild of America (LGA) couldn't prove beyond a doubt that Moreno had committed plagiarism, her suspicious behavior during the investigation raised suspicions. 

Witnesses described Moreno as agitated and dismissive, refusing to answer questions directly and eventually walking out of the inquiry. The LGA deemed her actions "a betrayal of the literary community and a discredit to the art of storytelling."

As a result, Moreno's prizes and honors were revoked, including a lucrative book deal with a major publishing house and a coveted teaching position at a respected writing program in California.

Witnesses described Lee as defensive and secretive, refusing to disclose her creative process and eventually hiring a lawyer to silence the inquiry. The ACA deemed her actions "a deceit of the art world and a disservice to the legacy of true masters."

Although the Authors Guild couldn't prove beyond a doubt that Wright had committed plagiarism, his contradictory statements during the investigation raised suspicions.
